fields.headline: May 1 2001
fields.bodyText: In a week that saw the publishing of some data suggesting that 4% of students are working in the sex industry just to make ends meet, here is this week's ultra focused email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals. As usual we take a look at the best graduate jobs, review last Saturday's Rise and there's a past article that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold. We even get a sneak preview of next week's edition. For anyone having trouble opening articles or accessing links, try cutting and pasting the URL (funny code included) into your internet browser. This will work better than clicking on the URLs from the email. If you didn't make it to the newsagent at the weekend, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 28 April). Continuing the theme of the oldest profession, Rise took its first look at brothels - digital brothels that is. Fiona Thompson suggests more of us will be working for Cyber-madams in the future and it's all legit. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,479642,00.html?bnr=email.grad Barbara Oaff offered her guide to surviving the last few weeks in the run up to finals. First thing to do is blitz the laundry and stock up the fridge. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,479646,00.html?bnr=email.grad NEXT WEEK'S RISE argues that it is possible for anyone to develop a "can-do" attitude. We examine what the future holds for graduates leaving agricultural college and we look at how networking through organisations such as the Junior Chambers of Commerce can advance your career. And there's another chance to win four months in the sun with the Volvo Environmental Scholarship. This week's RISE GOLD is a look at the some of the more unexpected things that can happen at interviews. Heard the one about the graduate who upon being invited to "surprise" his interviewer, set fire to his newspaper? http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3908292,00.html?bnr=email.grad THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP Get used to not exaggerating. One of the most common mistakes grads make at interviews is boasting about accomplishments beyond the realm of their experience. Allen Salikof of recruitment firm MRI says keep it honest and straightforward. THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS. If you definitely WEREN'T at the May Day demonstrations in London earlier this week, then Bloomberg is looking for Global Data Analysts with a degree in Economics or similar. "Show us an understanding of financial markets and even better, language skills, and we will want to show you around." http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115974,00.html?bnr=email.grad The Foreign & Commonwealth Office is looking for a research analyst to fill a vacancy within North Asia and Pacific Research Group. They want someone with intellectual strength and a good knowledge of Chinese affairs - and spy planes, presumably. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116242,00.html?bnr=email.grad And if you were in London on 1 May, the Centre for Sustainable Energy in Bristol is looking for a researcher who wants to "make a difference". You'll work on a variety of projects to influence Government policy. Got to know what fuel poverty is. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115525,00.html?bnr=email.grad If the Meejia is more your cup of tea, Fox Haynes Media Headhunters has got a new string of jobs with some big companies in a variety of areas - from media buying to sales. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116237,00.html?bnr=email.grad How about a career as a court stenographer? Smith Bernal International is seeking graduate students to train for one year to record what goes on in courts. It promises a guaranteed £12,000 training salary and the potential to earn £60K a year! http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115561,00.html?email.grad If you've an interest in chemistry and education - yes really - the Salters' Institute of Industrial Chemistry's looking for a camps administrator to organise several of its "highly successful residential chemistry camps for Year 10 students". Just don't let them set fire to the place. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116416,00.html?bnr=email.grad For those thinking of going down the TEFL route, GEOS has 487 English schools in Japan and needs "professional, committed graduates to teach in our schools in Japan". Most importantly, TEFL experience is an asset, but not essential. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116350,00.html?bnr=email.grad Just graduated in Interior design? Connaught Kitchens in London is looking for a design graduate with work experience. Got to have good drafting, CAD and project management skills - it's paying £18K. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116173,00.html?bnr=email.grad And finally, if you know which way to turn after canoeing up the Amazon, the Royal Geographical Society is looking for a computer literate graduate to help staff its Expedition Advisory Centre in London. Only £14K and you've got to be quick - closing deadline 4 May. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114698,00.html?bnr=email.grad
